_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.  Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

NCFI Polyurethanes is a flexible polyurethane foam manufacturing facility located in Mt. Airy, North Carolina.  As a result of the manufacturing process, the following regulated chemicals are present at the facility in quantities that exceed the threshold quantities specified by EPA regulations: toluene diisocyanate (TDI -10,000 pounds) and a pentane mixture (10,000 pounds).  The facility has two covered processes and meets the Program 1 requirements for TDI and Program 3 requirements for the pentane mixture of the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations  

TDI

TDI is delivered to the facility via railcars, truck, drums and totes and is offloaded into storage tanks.  In the process, TDI is used in the production of polyurethane foam. The facility manufactures polyurethane foam by the vigorous mechanical mixing of polyols with TDI along with water, catalyst and surfactants.  The resultant polymeric network is expanded with carbon dioxide which is formed in the reaction between the water and TDI.

Pentane Mixture

NCFI Polyurethanes uses two (2) different chemical components in the blending production of hydrocarbon based foam raw materials.  Polyol and a hydrocarbon blowing agent (the pentane mixture) are blended onsite to create the Poly Blend.    Three (3) different raw material polyols are transferred from the 3,000 gallon storage tanks located within the Pentane Operations Room into the adjacent Max Machinery Blending Unit to formulate the Polyol Blend.  

 

B. Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies 

NCFI Polyurethanes is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards.  Appropriate responses to releases of TDI are documented in the Section 7 of the Risk Management Program document.  Safety, environmental protection and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with commu

nity emergency responders for emergency planning and response efforts.



C.    Release Scenario Discussion

In accordance with the requirements of the RMP regulations each owner or operator of a stationary source is required to perform the following offsite consequence analyses.

??    One worst-case release scenario to represent all regulated toxic and flammable substances held in excess of the threshold quantity.  A worst-case release scenario were conducted for TDI and the pentane mixture.

??    One alternative release scenario for each regulated toxic substance held in excess of the threshold quantity.  An alternative release scenario was not required for TDI. An alternative release scenario was calculated for the pentane mixture.

The following are brief descriptions of the release scenarios that are being submitted by NCFI Polyurethanes.   

NCFI Polyurethanes elected to use ALOHA to calculate estimated release rates and to determine the distances to the TDI endpoint. NCFI Polyurethanes evaluated one worst-case release scenarios for TDI for inclusion in the Risk Management Plan (RMPlan). Since TDI is covered under Program 1, an alternative release scenario is not required.

NCFI Polyurethanes elected to use EPA's CAMEO Software to calculate the release rate and distance to the endpoint for the flammable pentane mixture. NCFI Polyurethanes evaluated one worst-case release scenario and two alternative case release scenarios for the pentane mixture for inclusion on the RMPlan.

Worst-Case Release Scenario

TDI

The worst-case toxic release scenario for NCFI Polyurethanes was determined to be an instantaneous liquid spill and vaporization of TDI from the largest vessel into a diked area.  A major release of this magnitude is extremely unlikely due to the advances that have taken place in the process design as well as the rigorous maintenance and prevention programs present at the NCFI Polyurethanes facility.  The EPA ALOHA model was used to estimate the distance to the t

oxic endpoint. The distance to the toxic endpoint did not extend off-site. No public receptors were within the distance to the toxic endpoint.

Pentane Mixture

The worst-case flammable release scenario for the pentane mixture was determined to be a vapor cloud explosion of the largest tank of the pentane mixture. A release of this magnitude is extremely unlikely due to the design and rigorous maintenance and prevention program present at the NCFI Polyurethanes facility. The distance to the toxic endpoint was the distance to an overpressure endpoint of 1 pound per square inch (psi).

Alternative Release Scenario

TDI

An alternative release scenario was not required for TDI. 

Pentane Mixture

For the pentane mixture two alternative release scenarios were considered and evaluated.

D.    Five-year Accident History

Under the EPA RMP regulations, an accidental release is defined as a release of a regulated substance that "resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage."  Within the past five years, NCFI Polyurethanes has had no accidents that meet these requirements.

E.    Prevention Program (Pentane Mixture)

Employee Participation

In accordance with the requirements of OSHA's PSM regulations and EPA's RMP regulations, NCFI Polyurethanes has developed and implemented written procedures, which ensure all employees working in the pentane mixture areas, or directly on the design and/or safety review of the Covered Process are:

??    Aware of and are actively involved in the development of the information comprising its RMP/PSM Plan 

??    Consulted prior to any revisions to its RMP/PSM Plan; and

??    Actively involved with the development of any new or revised procedures included in its RMP/PSM Plan.

The overall administration and management of the RMP/PSM Plan is the responsibility of the Human Resources Manager.  The President of NCFI Polyureth

anes is ultimately responsible for ensuring the appropriate employees are actively involved in the initial development of the RMP/PSM Plan and in any subsequent revisions.

Process Safety Information

In accordance with the requirements of OSHA's PSM regulations and EPA's RMP regulations, NCFI Polyurethanes has completed this compilation of process safety information pertaining to the pentane mixture as described in the PSM.  The compilation of written process safety information is to enable the employer and the employees involved in operating the process to identify and understand the hazards posed by the processes involving the pentane mixture.  This process safety information includes information pertaining to the technology of the process, and information pertaining to the equipment in the process. This information has been compiled from a variety of sources, including Supplier Safety Data Sheets (SDS), equipment specification sheets, as well as electrical, structural, fire and mechanical design drawings.

Process Hazard Analysis

In accordance with the requirements of OSHA's PSM regulations and EPA's RMP regulations, NCFI Polyurethanes has used the PHA process to pinpoint weaknesses in the design and operation of facilities that could lead to accidental chemical releases, fires, or explosions. The PHA has provided NCFI Polyurethanes with information to help improve the safety, determine the hazards and potential failure points or failure modes in the pentane mixture process and manage the risk of the operation.

Operating Procedures

In accordance with the requirements contained in OSHA's PSM regulations and EPA's RMP regulations, NCFI Polyurethanes has developed written operating procedures for operations directly affecting the safety of the pentane mixture process, as well as operational procedures where, if not followed properly, could lead to a spill or release of flammable materials. These procedures provide clear, concise instructions for safely conductin

g activities involved in phases of operation within the process. The primary responsibility for the normal operation of the pentane mixture process will belong to the Operators. In instances other than normal operations, operation of the system will be performed by NCFI Polyurethanes engineering, maintenance, or management personnel or under their direct supervision. Initial startup will be accomplished under direct management supervision.



Training

In accordance with the requirements of OSHA PSM regulations and EPA's RMP regulations, NCFI Polyurethanes has developed and implemented a training program for all of its employees involved with the operation of the pentane mixture process.  The training program, provides an overview of the process, its equipment, and operating procedures while placing a specific emphasis on safety and health hazards (associated with the process and the chemicals involved), emergency operations (specifically shutdown), safe work practices, and emergency response procedures. 

Contractor Safety

NCFI Polyurethanes recognizes the need to help prevent hazards associated with work performed at its facility by contractors and other on-site workers who are not under direct NCFI Polyurethanes supervision. In an effort to help provide a safe work environment for NCFI Polyurethane's employees as well as for contractor's employees, NCFI Polyurethanes has developed and implemented a Contractor Safety Program (CSP). The CSP is also intended to facilitate the evaluation of contractor safety performance, to assist in contract selection and to ensure that contractors have completed appropriate safety orientations and training prior to the commencement of work. 

Management of Change

In accordance with the requirements of OSHA's PSM regulations and EPA's RMP regulations, NCFI Polyurethanes has developed and implemented written procedures for the management of changes (MOC) proposed for the pentane mixture process. These procedures apply to all propos

ed changes in the process chemicals, technology, equipment, operating procedures, and any proposed changes to the stationary source which may affect the pentane mixture storage and blending operations. 

The purpose of the MOC procedures is to assure that the following considerations are addressed prior to any change in the process:

??    The technical basis for the proposed change is defined.

??    The impact of the proposed change on safety and health is defined.

??    Determine what, if any, modifications to operating procedures would be required by the proposed change.

??    Define the time period necessary for implementation of the proposed change.

??    Ensure that prior to proceeding with any proposed change that the appropriate NCFI Polyurethanes management personnel authorize the change.

Mechanical Integrity

In accordance with the requirements of OSHA's PSM regulations and EPA's RMP regulations, NCFI Polyurethanes has developed and implemented written procedures to maintain the initial installation, as well as on-going mechanical and operational integrity of the components of pentane mixture process.  

Engineering specifications, data sheets, operations maintenance manuals and CAD electronic files have been provided by Spectrum the engineering group that assisted NCFI Polyurethanes with the PSM program implementation, as well as local construction and service vendors directly contracted by NCFI Polyurethanes.  In addition, hard copies of equipment specifications, parts lists, and data sheets from vendors have been provided in a separate binder from this written PSM Plan, which identify the cut sheets for the respective equipment and instrumentation specified and installed by the respective contractors or NCFI Polyurethanes personnel.  

Mechanical Integrity and Periodic or Preventative Maintenance procedures apply to the following equipment and controls in the pentane mixture process.

??    Bulk storage tanks (including tank components such as level controls, pressu

uld include:  commissioning, introducing hazardous chemical, or introducing energy.  This review is designed to confirm that prior to the introduction of pentane mixture process into a process that:

??    Construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications;

??    Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;

??    For new facilities, a PHA has been conducted and all recommendations have been resolved / implemented prior to startup;

??    For modified facilities, that changes have been evaluated by the MOC procedures and all subsequent revisions to the PSM/RMP Plan made; and

??    General Awareness PSM Training of each employee involved with the operation of the process has been completed.

Incident Investigation

In accordance with OSHA's PSM regulations and EPA's RMP regulations, NCFI Polyurethanes has developed and implemented an Incident Investigation Program (IIP). The purpose of the IIP is to ensure the thorough investigation of any incident or "near miss" which results in, or could reasonably result in, any injury or unplanned/unanticipated release of chemicals in the workplace.  

Through the procedures outlined in this IIP, NCFI Polyurethanes will identify the underlying root cause of any incident or near miss in order to develop and implement steps to prevent similar events from occurring in the future. The overriding purpose of each incident investigation is to allow NCFI Polyurethanes to learn from its experiences and to prevent recurrences. NCFI Polyurethanes will make its best effort to obtain accurate factual information without assigning blame to any person or party.

Compliance Audits

In accordance with the requirements of OSHA's PSM regulations and EPA's RMP regulations, NCFI Polyurethanes has implemented a compliance audit program to verify that the procedures and practices contained in its PSM/RMP Plans are adequate and are being followed. It is the ultimate responsibility of the Plant Manager to

ensure these procedures are followed.

F.    Emergency Response Program

NCFI Polyurethanes is included in the community emergency response plan.  The emergency response plan includes:

??    Procedures for informing the Surry County LEPC and the community about any accidental releases;

??    Documentation of first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental exposures; and

??    Procedures for emergency response after and accidental release of a regulated substance.

G.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

In an effort to improve safety and to reduce the risk of accidental releases, changes to the RMProgram and the facility have been implemented.  These improvements were identified either as risk reduction measures during the PHA or as a result of an improved RMProgram and the dedication to an inherently safer process.
